image.altText: Hundreds of pelicans are seen across an inland lake.

items.synopsis: A group of scientists finds despite billions of dollars spent on the Murray Darling Basin Plan, many of the indicators used to measure whether the environment is receiving enough water have been getting worse.

title.children: First pelican breeding frenzy at lake since 1999 sustained by buying water from farmers, scientists say

image.altText: A comparison of teeth from three koalas species.

items.synopsis: Scientists say teeth from the species have been found at a 25-million-year-old fossil bed south of Alice Springs. It is the first-ever record of koalas living in the Northern Territory.

title.children: New prehistoric koala species 'about the size of a cat' discovered in Central Australian fossil bed

image.altText: Woman in a straw hat holds a large live barramundi

items.synopsis: The all-women Secret Women's Business Barra Challenge takes place at Corroboree Billabong outside Darwin each year, with government figures revealing more women fish recreationally in the NT than men.

title.children: Women recreational fishers outpace men in NT as Barra Challenge draws hundreds

image.altText: Prince William, Kate, Princess of Wales, Prince Harry, and Meghan at the Queen's funeral.

items.synopsis: The plans for her death were meticulous. Her lavish funeral had a code name. But when the kingdom's second Elizabethan era drew to a close, everyone suddenly seemed to be a little caught off-guard.

title.children: 'I was welcome at Balmoral … but without her': How family tensions gripped the Queen's final hours

image.altText: Sunrise over the Moylan Grain Silos plant in Kellerberrin.

items.synopsis: The tight-knit WA community of Kellerberrin faces a long road to recovery after a father was shot dead by another well-known local resident, sparking a manhunt and police stand-off that forced the town into lockdown.

title.children: Terrorised by one of its own, small town reels after gunman kills local father before turning weapon on himself

image.altText: A man in a white shirt looks into a food delivery bag

items.synopsis: An analysis of data from China's second largest food delivery service shows that adding a "green nudge" could eliminate more than 3 million tonnes of single-use plastic.

title.children: A simple 'green nudge' could save millions of tonnes of plastic waste each year

image.altText: Vivienne Mitchell's face and upper body is superimposed over a picture of razors that has a price tag of $43

items.synopsis: Backlash against Coles and Woolworths is swirling on social media as the supermarket giants record large profits amid a cost of living crisis. But one expert says the anger, and calls for a boycott, are unlikely to have a lasting effect.

title.children: How one Australian's 'sheer disbelief' at the rising cost of groceries reached 1.7 million shoppers

image.altText: Catherine King standing speaking wearing a bright red blazer.

items.synopsis: Could her resurrection of the 2020 strip search incident be one way of seeking to neutralise an issue that has been otherwise debated – to the government's detriment – in terms of limiting competition?

title.children: Catherine King's baffling week leaves more questions than answers on Qatar decision

image.altText: Military officials look at nuclear sub with red star on its front

items.synopsis: The new vessel — named Hero Kim Kun Ok after a North Korean historical figure — will be assigned to the fleet that patrols the waters between the Korean peninsula and Japan.

title.children: North Korea launches new tactical nuclear attack submarine

image.altText: Danny Masterson wears a face mask looking straight ahead in front of an orange background.

items.synopsis: A US judge sentences That ’70s Show star Danny Masterson to 30 years to life in prison for the rapes of two women two decades ago.

title.children: That '70s Show actor Danny Masterson jailed for 30 years to life for raping two women

image.altText: A satellite image showing Australia, New Zealand and an enormous mushroom cloud from a volcanic eruption in the Pacific ocean

items.synopsis: In January 2022, a mega explosion from the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano generated a coast-battering tsunami and vivid sunsets. Now we know the extent of the eruption's devastation below the waves.

title.children: 'Removed all life': Beneath the waves, Tongan volcano's eruption laid waste to the sea floor

image.altText: Gerard Rennick sits on the backbench in the Senate looking into the distance

items.synopsis: Coalition senator Gerard Rennick has questioned the basis for claims Australia's Indigenous history dates back more than 60,000 years. What do the experts say?

title.children: What's the evidence for 60,000 years of Indigenous history?

image.altText: A man stands looking at a pile of rubble and bricks that has crashed down

items.synopsis: Items set to be used at a young couple's wedding are lost when a tree destroyed their garage as Sydney is hit by a night of wind damage.

title.children: Wild winds lash Sydney, battering homes and blowing off roofs

image.altText: Peter speaks outside court and gestures with his right hand as protesters stand behind him.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Former Trump adviser convicted of contempt of congress. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Associated Press The US Open semifinal between Coco Gauff and Karolina Muchova was delayed early in the second set because of a disruption by environmental activists in the Arthur Ashe Stadium stands. Gauff was ahead 6-4, 1-0 when play was halted for at least 40 minutes. Tournament referee Jake Garner came out onto the court, while security headed toward where the protesters were. They were wearing shirts that read End Fossil Fuels. At least one person glued their feet to the ground, making it harder to be removed, a spokesman for the US Tennis Association said. At least two protesters were taken away. Later, more than a half-dozen police officers arrived — greeted by cheers from fans near the section where the disruption happened.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Climate protest interrupts US Open semifinal for 40 minutes

children.content: was delayed early in the second set because of a disruption by environmental activists in the Arthur Ashe Stadium stands.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former foreign minister Marise Payne has announced she'll retire as a senator for New South Wales. A trailblazing politician, she spent almost three decades in the federal parliament, becoming the first female defence minister. She also served as the minister for women and was a senior figure in the republic movement before entering politics. In a statement, the Liberal politician says she will quit the Senate at the end of the month, calling time on her 26 years in federal politics. The party will pre-select her replacement in the months to come.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Former foreign minister Marise Payne has announced she'll retire

children.content: has announced she'll retire as a senator for New South Wales.

props.alt: A close up of Marise looking seriously to the side at an outdoor press conference.

children.content: A trailblazing politician, she spent almost three decades in the federal parliament, becoming the first female defence minister.
She also served as the minister for women and was a senior figure in the republic movement before entering politics.
In a statement, the Liberal politician says she will quit the Senate at the end of the month, calling time on her 26 years in federal politics.
The party will pre-select her replacement in the months to come.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: King Charles has thanked the public for the "love and support" on the first anniversary of the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth. Britain's longest-reigning sovereign died aged 96 at Balmoral Castle, leading to 10 days of national mourning for her record-breaking 70-year reign. To mark the anniversary, King Charles has released one of his favourite official portraits of the late Queen, captured at Buckingham Palace in 1968. He has also re-pledged his own service to the nation. "We recall with great affection her long life, devoted service and all she meant to so many of us. "I am deeply grateful, too, for the love and support that has been shown to my wife and myself … as we do our utmost to be of service to you all."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: King Charles thanks public for the 'love' as he marks death of mother, Queen Elizabeth

image.altText: Barbed wire on the fence at Don Dale

items.synopsis: The government has been ordered by the NT Supreme Court to pay $960,000 to four former detainees who were unlawfully tear gassed in 2014.

title.children: NT government 'considering legal options' over nearly $1m Don Dale compensation ruling

image.altText: QANTAS dreamliner in Alice Springs in 2018

items.synopsis: Further airline services have been cut to central Australia Iin Alan Joyce's final act as outgoing Qantas chief. The move is prompting the Northern Territory tourism minister, Nicole Manison to welcome Joyce's retirement.

title.children: Latest Qantas cuts to Alice Springs has NT minister welcoming Alan Joyce's departure

image.altText: A selfie of a serious man with shaved hair next to his large brown dog.

items.synopsis: Surfer Tony Begg is lucky to be alive after being attacked by a shark on a NSW beach. The off-duty doctor who saved him says he is a "fighter".

title.children: It's 'absolutely crazy' he survived, says responding off-duty doctor after shark attack

image.altText: A page in the Voice to Parliament referendum booklet highlighting the need to read information from trusted sources

items.synopsis: We've got a date for the vote, but we're still waiting for the writ to be issued. But that could happen today or Monday.

title.children: Voice to Parliament referendum postal vote applications aren't open yet. Here's why

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Scott Morrison

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Scott Morrison has warned that his successor should not be "too keen" to accept an invitation to China, as Anthony Albanese prepares to visit Beijing within months.

title.children: Scott Morrison says Anthony Albanese shouldn't rush to visit Beijing this year

image.altText: Man in red jacket with light on his head

items.synopsis: The operation to rescue the experienced US cave researcher from the depths of southern Türkiye's Taurus Mountains involves teams from Bulgaria, Croatia, Hungary, Italy, Poland and Türkiye.

title.children: Race to save injured explorer 1,000 metres inside cave in Türkiye

image.altText: Russia's President Vladimir Putin, India's PM Narendra Modi and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

items.synopsis: When the G20 began in 2008 against a backdrop of a global economic crisis, nations came together to fix problems both internationally and at home. Fifteen years later, the event is struggling to even get a full list of attendees.

title.children: Demolished slums, new roads, and animal control: India is going all out for G20, but is it still relevant?

image.altText: People cross the road at an intersection in a busy CBD.

items.synopsis: Wall Street finished lower overnight in response to China's ban on iPhones, while corporate regulator ASIC is suing AustralianSuper for allegedly failing to address multiple superannuation accounts belonging to 90,000 customers. Follow live.

title.children: ASIC sues AustralianSuper over $69m 'failure' affecting 90,000 customers, China's iPhone ban hits Wall Street, ASX flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Workers at Chevron's two major liquified natural gas (LNG) projects in WA will begin strike action this afternoon, after mediation talks failed to deliver a resolution. Chevron workers have been arguing for better pay and rostering, and had threatened to start strike action yesterday, before mediation talks were held by the Fair Work Commission. Now, union body Offshore Alliance says those talks have failed to resolve their demands, and strike action will begin from 1pm WST (3pm AEST) — including workers at Gorgon, Australia's second-largest LNG plant, and Wheatstone. The ongoing dispute between Chevron and its workers has been swirling for weeks, and follows the threat of Woodside workers threatening to walk off the job, which sent the price of LNG soaring globally. Australia is the biggest exporter of LNG in the world, and although it mainly supplies customers in Asia, the threat of industrial action has impacted prices in Europe, too. With the strike action now set to go ahead this afternoon, it could disrupt 7% of the global supply of LNG. Here's the full statement from Offshore Alliance's Facebook page: "Despite the Offshore Alliance giving Chevron plenty of opportunity to sort out EBA's across the 3 Chevron facilities, they will finally be facing their day of reckoning. Protected Industrial Action commences at 13:00 today. "Chevron are demanding they be given special concessions in bargaining — a demand which we have put through the shredding machine. "Their bargaining performance has been the most inept effort of any employer the Union has dealt with in the past 5 years and our members have had enough. "When PIA commences, plant on each respective facility will be shut down if there are not competent personnel to undertake handovers during work stoppages. "It's game on, Chevron." Chevron has reportedly made provisions for when workers down tools. Woodside's dispute with its North West Shelf workers was resolved late last month, guaranteeing pay packets of more than $300,000 a year .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Game on': Chevron workers to begin strike at 3pm AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local sharemarket has opened flat on Friday morning, sitting at 7,170 points at 10:20am AEST. (If you want the latest figures, head to the top of the blog.) It's pretty muted across the sectors so far, too. Utilities is up 0.4%, consumer non-cyclicals +0.2%, and healthcare and financials up 0.1% each. Industrials, energy and basic materials are the sectors in the most negative territory, down 0.8% each, while real estate is down 0.3%, and technology and consumer cyclicals have dipped 0.1% each. Meanwhile, news that Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will visit Beijing later this year has seen a positive jump for Treasury Wine Estates. The top movers so far: Treasury Wine Estates +2.9% Paladin Energy +2% Bellevue Gold +1.7% Boral +1.4% Auckland International Airport +1.4% And the bottom movers: Link Administration -3.5% Block -3.1% Mineral Resources -3% Nine Entertainment -2.4% Sayona Mining -2.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens flat as Treasury Wine Estate leads the gains

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Telstra has issued a short release on the ASX confirming that it's in talks to purchase Melbourne-based cloud consultant Versent. It follows reporting in the Australian Financial Review this week, which mentioned the deal was expected to be worth about $400 million. Telstra has confirmed it is in talks about a potential purchase of the company, but it is still in its early stages. "Telstra confirms it is participating in the process," the statement read. "References to the value of the offer are speculative. "There is no certainty a transaction involving Telstra will eventuate, should a transaction be finalised Telstra will update the market accordingly."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Telstra confirms it's in talks to purchase cloud consultant Versent

image.altText: Naomi Bowden

items.synopsis: Through tears Naomi Bowden tells a NSW inquiry into birth trauma how distressing it was to have police take her stillborn daughter and put her in an ice box in front of her.

title.children: Naomi speaks up about the 'disrespectful' treatment she received after her baby was stillborn

image.altText: China 6G

items.synopsis: Chinese state media has pointed to Huawei's new smartphone as evidence the United States' attempts to curtail China's microchip development are failing. So how significant is the tech in the new phone and what does it mean for the "chip wars"?

title.children: Huawei launched a new phone without fanfare last week. But the technology it uses has sparked intense debate

image.altText: Close up of Catherine King

items.synopsis: Transport Minister Catherine King has pledged airfares will soon come down, saying Qatar Airways is "not the only airline that adds to competition".

title.children: Catherine King says airfares 'will come down' as other airlines increase capacity

image.altText: A composite picture of Qatar Airways and Qantas airliners on the tarmac.

items.synopsis: A decision announced in July to deny Qatar Airways more flights to major Australian cities has resulted in accusations of protectionism for Qantas, criticism from the private sector and ACCC, and a parliamentary inquiry. This is how it all unfolded.

title.children: How a government decision over flight routes saw Qantas grilled and parliament launch an inquiry

image.altText: Sgt Richard Monei sits at table with police hat next to him

items.synopsis: Richard Monaei joined the Queensland Police Service when he was 18. He's now an advocate so other First Nations people don't suffer as he did.

title.children: Racism forced Richard out of Queensland Police. He says a newly announced review is 'long overdue'

image.altText: A surveillance camera is silhouetted behind a Chinese national flag in Beijing.

items.synopsis: Proposed changes to a Chinese public security law to criminalise comments, clothing or symbols that "undermine the spirit" or "harm the feelings" of the country trigger the concern of legal experts, who say the amendments could be used arbitrarily.

title.children: China's draft law banning 'harming the feelings' of the country sparks backlash

image.altText: The Webb Ellis Cup is held up in the air.

title.children: Who the Wallabies are up against at the Rugby World Cup 2023

image.altText: a man ina lab coat leaning on a large furnace

items.synopsis: A furnace that reaches 3,000 degrees Celsius is helping scientists make parts for hypersonic jets and test components for space travel and defence.

title.children: This furnace is the hottest in the southern hemisphere, and it's used to make hypersonic jets

image.altText: Belinda and Kobee Huddy smile for a selfie.

items.synopsis: Early one May morning in 2019, 20-year-old Kobee Huddy was desperate for help. He called a mental health service for advice. Less than four hours later he would be dead – shot by police.

title.children: Did Kobee's cry for help kill him? How a knife-wielding mentally ill young man was fatally shot by police

image.altText: Myanmar Now photojournalist Sai Zaw Thaike.

items.synopsis: A court in Myanmar sentences a photojournalist for an underground news agency to 20 years in prison with hard labour for his coverage of a deadly cyclone's aftermath.

title.children: Myanmar photojournalist jailed for 20 years over cyclone aftermath reporting

image.altText: An aerial photo showing the RACV resort near the coastline.

items.synopsis: A coastal council is calling on the Victorian government to develop policies that provide certainty for seaside communities amid concerns erosion and rising sea levels will leave them unrecognisable.

title.children: Victorian council calls for state support to protect coastal communities from climate change

image.altText: An aerial view of flooded parts of Echuca.

items.synopsis: A northern Victorian council has approved 16 townhouses to be built on land that was significantly flooded in the Murray River town of Echuca during last year's flood.

title.children: 'Absolutely crazy': Developer gets approval to build 16 homes on site of Echuca 'inland sea'

image.altText: A magnified image of tuberculosis.

items.synopsis: SA Health says 13 people have tested positive for the potentially deadly disease in the Aṉangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) Lands since the outbreak started in March.

title.children: 'Extremely concerning' tuberculosis outbreak in far north South Australia prompts testing blitz
